text: In addition to using the name America, we will also refer to the continent as Abya Yala, a term used by the indigenous peoples of the continent (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).
The abbreviations A.E.C, B.C.E (Before Common Era), and negative years serve as generalizations for representing eras preceding the initial days of the calendars.

Prerequisites

To better understand the concept of time, we suggest that readers first study the following resources:

  • Chronology: Introduces the reader to various systems of chronology used in historical studies, explaining how they help organize and interpret events within their temporal context.
  • Understanding the time: a study of how different civilizations measure time.
  • Understanding the time continuity: an examination of time in nature.

Introduction

In some cases, when we are introduced to human history, we observe a sequence of events that often lacks important information. A common example is the description of discoveries of new lands where people already lived (History Tracers Team, , Who truly discovered America (Abya Yala)?). In this text, we aim to fill some of these gaps by highlighting the "forgotten" cradles of civilization (Peru: Cradle of Civilization. Museo Larco).

What is a civilization?

Before discussing the cradles of civilization, it is important to start with the definition of "civilization" ("civilization", Cambridge Dictionary):

• "human society with its well developed social organizations, or the culture and way of life of a society or country at a particular period in time: Cuzco was the centre of one of the world's most famous civilizations, that of the Incas."
This definition of "civilization" is well-suited for our study. It is not restrictive and even provides an example of a civilization. However, this leads to an important question for reflection:

Reflection 1: The first

Was there a civilization that served as the foundation for all others?

Mesopotamia

The Mesopotamian region is located between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, corresponding to the present-day country of Iraq (Soden, W. Th. von , Frye, . Richard N. and Edzard, . Dietz O., ). This area is known as the cradle of some of the oldest civilizations of humanity, such as the Sumerians, Akkadians, Babylonians, and Assyrians.
In his article, Zohrab S. Demirdjian discusses the path toward building a civilization and where such developments first emerged. He asserts (Demirdjian, Z. S., , pp. 103):

• "After all, Mesopotamia is considered to be thre cradle of civilizations and marketing must began there... man's progress toward civilization by moving from Hunter-Gatherer (Nomadic Life), to Metallurgy (Tools), to Agriculture (Trade), to Urbanization (Settled Life), to namely Civilization."

While this perspective is widely accepted, it is essential to note that not all civilizations followed this exact trajectory. Some developed tools without the use of metallurgy, as we will explore further.
The Mesopotamian region, part of the so-called "Crescent Fertil", witnessed significant advancements in agriculture, urbanization, trade, science, religion, and the development of writing systems.

Mesopotamian languages belong to the Semitic language family, known for their shared morphology. However, modern linguistic research suggests that these languages are not the original source but instead evolved from an earlier group known as Proto-Afro-Asiatic languages (Wolff, H. Ekkehard, , Encyclopedia Britannica ; Testen, D., , Encyclopedia Britannica). A notable example of ancient text written in this language family is the "Sumerian King List", housed in the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford (Ashmolean Museum Oxford ; Cartwright, M., , World History Encyclopedia):

Conclusions

Now, imagine you have never studied the civilizations of the Indus Valley, Egypt, China, Mesoamerica, or the Andes. If someone presented you with a linear view of history, claiming that civilization began exclusively in Mesopotamia, how would you answer the question: "Where did civilization arise?"

Science is constantly evolving, and for a long time, Mesopotamia was commonly referred to as the first known civilization, emerging around (Demirdjian, Z. S., , pp. 104). However, recent research in history and biological sciences has shown that Mesopotamia was not the only cradle of civilization. Other civilizations emerged independently, without direct contact with Mesopotamian peoples.

For instance, Jesuit priest José de Acosta, writing in the 16th century (Gregorian calendar), mentioned that Indigenous people of the Americas (Abya Ayla) arrived from Asia. Genetic research has since confirmed this theory, showing that humans migrated to the Americas (Abya Ayla) long before any civilizations were established in Mesopotamia (Acosta, José, [ , ()], pp. 240 ; Puente, Francisco Barriga, , pp. 15 - 16 ; O’Rourke, Dennis H., and Jennifer A. Raff., ; Goebel, Ted, et al., ; Pirula, ; Pirula, ; Iamarino, Atila, ). This demonstrates that American civilizations arose independently.

Furthermore, when studying other regions near Mesopotamia, we observe other potential cradles of civilization. For example, the Armenians are the only civilization to have survived the Mesopotamian peoples and are mentioned in ancient Babylonian texts. Writing systems also developed independently in other regions, such as Egypt and the Harappan civilization in present-day Pakistan (Demirdjian, Z. S., , pp. 110 - 112 ; Finkel, I, , The British Museum ).

Andes

For a long time, the American continent (Abya Yala) was mistakenly considered devoid of civilizations before the arrival of colonizers, despite substantial evidence to the contrary. Today, it is known that two major regions developed distinct civilizations, though there is no consensus on whether they had direct contact (Melko, M., , pp. 150 - 152 ; Melgar Tísoc, Emiliano, ).

The Andes mountain range extends across South America, from Venezuela to the southern parts of Chile and Argentina. Historically, the term "Andean" primarily refers to the people living in the central regions of the Andes, particularly those under the influence of the Inca Empire, which controlled a vast area (Murra, J. V., ).

The Andean civilizations are as ancient as some Mesopotamian civilizations, with artifacts dating back over four thousand years. Their advancements continue to be uncovered. In , miniature models of their cities were discovered (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ; Zona Caral, ; de la Morena, Raquel, ).
Figure 2: Pyramid H1 at the archaeological site of Caral (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ). Photo taken in during a visit to the site.

One factor that contributed to the misconception that Andean people did not have a civilization was the supposed absence of a writing system. However, recent studies suggest that the knots (quipus) could be more than just a numerical system, potentially encoding information similar to writing (Mann, Charles C., , pp. 1008 ; Hyland, S., ; Cartwright, M., ; Laurencich Minelli, L., ; Urton, G., ; Moras, Roberto, ; Moras, Roberto, ).
Figure 3: Panel at the archaeological site of Caral, ©ZonaArqueólogicaCaral, (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ). Photo taken on during a visit to the site.

Between the rise of Caral and the fall of the Inca Empire, nearly five thousand years passed. Caral and the Incas were not the only cultures in the Andes; dozens of other cultures and civilizations have been identified, and it is likely that many more are yet to be discovered (Lumbreras, Luis G., ).

Mesoamerica

The concept of Mesoamerica was first defined in by anthropologist Paul Kirchhoff. Initially, it included the region between Guatemala and Mexico, but further archaeological research expanded its boundaries to include present-day Costa Rica (Creamer, W., , pp. 35 - 55).

In the Andes, the possible absence of a writing system was initially considered a barrier to classifying its cultures as civilizations. Conversely, in Mesoamerica, the issue was the limited use of metallurgy. This contrast leads us to an important reflection:

On Achievements

Should we view as a success, rather than a limitation, the fact that different civilizations achieved comparable advancements using distinct tools and resources?
Recent research has shown that metallurgy did, in fact, exist in Mesoamerica at certain points in time, challenging the notion that this technology was absent (Hosler, D., ).

Regarding Mesoamerican civilizations, hieroglyphic writing systems were used to record historical events in city-states like the Maya and empires like the Aztec (Mora-Marín, D. F., ; Oudijk, Michel R,, ; Kettunen, Harri et al., ).
Figure 4: Altar, stela, and the largest hieroglyphic text found at the archaeological site of Copán (Instituto Hondureño de Antropologia e Historia, ). Photo taken on during a visit to the site.

Another notable aspect of Mesoamerican civilizations is their precise timekeeping, made possible by their advanced counting systems. These were often associated with monumental structures used to measure the seasons of the year (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 33 - 35 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , pp. 33 - 35 (Revista) ; Ocampo, Estela; Bidon-Chanal, Carlos, , pp. 175).

Photo taken on during a visit to the museum.

Like the Andean civilizations, it has not yet been possible to fully map all the cultures and civilizations of Mesoamerica. Technologies such as LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) are being used to detect ancient cities hidden within dense forests, leading to new discoveries about these societies (¿Qué es LiDAR?, IBM; Clynes, Tom. Escudero, Rubén S., ; Moras, Roberto, ).

Interdisciplinarity

When comparing civilizations, we must be cautious not to assume that similar-looking objects or sculptures originate from the same civilization solely because they appear alike (History Tracers Team, , Sobre igualdade). While the possibility of making mistakes exists, this should not prevent us from comparing civilizations to better understand each one. Let’s begin with the biological sciences:

Biology in History

The initial arrival of humans on the American continent (Abya Yala) was not discovered through written texts but rather through artifacts found in the Clovis region, dated to around 13,000 years ago—roughly 8,000 years before the rise of the first civilizations in Mesopotamia (Goebel, Ted, et al., , pp. 1499).

Similarly, recent studies have been helping us better understand the writing systems in South America and the arrival of metallurgy in Mesoamerica. Biological sciences have confirmed the independent emergence of these civilizations and have also helped precisely determine migration periods. Molecular evidence, such as changes in DNA, indicates that our species left Africa about 50,000 years ago, reached Central Asia around 40,000 years ago, and migrated from Siberia to the Americas sometime between 30,000 and 13,000 years ago, with the most likely time being around 22,000 years ago (Goebel, Ted, et al., , pp. 1500-1501). These migrations occurred at different times.
The understanding of ancient texts can be greatly enhanced by combining historical analysis with knowledge from geography, physics, and mathematics.

Geography, Physics, and Mathematics in History

By studying the Sumerian King List (Figure 1), we observe the mention of a flood on a global scale (Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ). However, if we interpret "global" in the sense we use it in the 21st century (Gregorian calendar), this would imply that the flood also affected the American (Abya Yala) continent.

Since the lifespans listed for the Sumerian kings are incompatible with human life as we know it (Eileen M. Crimmins, ), it is necessary to find and date artifacts to verify their existence and the period in which they lived. Researchers successfully did this for Enmebaragesi, whose existence was confirmed through a piece dated between and . His son, Aga, is mentioned in a meeting with Gilgamesh, the king of Ur, who is said to have survived a flood (RIME 1.07.22.02, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; Gilgamesh epic). With these dates in hand, we can compare them to the timeline of construction in Caral, Peru. The buildings in Caral, dated between and (Solis, R. S., Haas, J., & Creamer, W., ), were not affected by the flood described in the Sumerian texts.

By cross-referencing data from different sciences with historical records, we confirm that human migration occurred well before the rise of Mesopotamian civilizations. Furthermore, we can demonstrate that while catastrophic events were unfolding in Mesopotamia, life continued as usual in Caral. This raises the question: Did the Mesopotamians have any understanding of the true extent of the flood (History Tracers Team, )? The answer can be found in the British Museum, where a "Map of the World" as understood by the Babylonians, is exhibited. None of the places represented in the map include distant regions or even nearby areas such as Egypt or India (Finkel, I, , The British Museum ; The British Museum).

Conclusion

In this text, we explored three civilizations that arose independently. We have seen how other sciences, in conjunction with history, help us interpret ancient texts that often seem to describe global events but are, in fact, referring to local phenomena.
